description.md: Student reporter David Hogg at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School spoke with his classmates while hiding from the deadly shooting: "I wanted to be a junior NRA member ... now I can't even fathom the idea of a gun in my house."

Map The Movement was created by Youth Radio Interactive, where young people mix journalism, design, and code.

Youth Team: Devin Glover, Desmond Meagley, Seth Marceau, Thadius Prescott, Nina Roehl

Staff: Asha Richardson, Radamés Ajna, Teresa Chin, Lissa Soep

Youth Radio is a national network of next-generation reporters, artists, and storytellers. If you're one of the above, join our community by emailing contact info and links to pitch@youthradio.org.

body.md:
### A Movement Born In Tragedy

The massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School takes place shortly before the end of the school day on February 14, 2018. Seventeen students and school staff die after a 19-year-old former student opens fire.
body.html:
A Movement Born In Tragedy

The massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School takes place shortly before the end of the school day on February 14, 2018. Seventeen students and school staff die after a 19-year-old former student opens fire.

body.md:
### What We Really Need Is Action 

Rejecting “thoughts and prayers” from politicians, teen survivors of the Parkland shooting call instead for concrete reforms of gun control. Days after the shooting, they start planning a #NationalSchoolWalkout and a #March4Ourlives.
body.html:
What We Really Need Is Action

Rejecting “thoughts and prayers” from politicians, teen survivors of the Parkland shooting call instead for concrete reforms of gun control. Days after the shooting, they start planning a #NationalSchoolWalkout and a #March4Ourlives.

body.md:
### The Movement Spreads


Inspired by the Parkland students, young people around the country begin their own local forms of activism. Businesses and politicians take notice and some change policies, including cutting ties with the NRA.
body.html:
The Movement Spreads

Inspired by the Parkland students, young people around the country begin their own local forms of activism. Businesses and politicians take notice and some change policies, including cutting ties with the NRA.

body.md:
### Schools Prepare For Massive Student Walkout


Leading up to March 14th walkout, some schools decide to embrace student activism. Others, not so much.
body.html:
Schools Prepare For Massive Student Walkout

Leading up to March 14th walkout, some schools decide to embrace student activism. Others, not so much.

body.md:
### National School Walkouts 3/14

Despite freezing cold temperatures, rain, and -- in some cases -- threats of disciplinary action, students across the country walk out of class to demand tighter gun controls.
body.html:
National School Walkouts 3/14

Despite freezing cold temperatures, rain, and -- in some cases -- threats of disciplinary action, students across the country walk out of class to demand tighter gun controls.

body.md:
# With #MarchForOurLives, Activists Demand Action

On Saturday, March 24th, students and allies from across the United States marched in Washington D.C. and in communities across the country with one message: #Enough.
body.html:
With #MarchForOurLives, Activists Demand Action

On Saturday, March 24th, students and allies from across the United States marched in Washington D.C. and in communities across the country with one message: #Enough.

body.md:
### A Student-Led Movement Demands Student-Led Coverage.



_"There’s no central leader. It’s a team effort. That’s what’s most important"_ -- Alex Wind, who survived the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.

On the street, at government offices, and via social media: young people are calling for gun control at a national scale. The movement is everywhere, and here are some highlights.
body.html:
A Student-Led Movement Demands Student-Led Coverage.

"There’s no central leader. It’s a team effort. That’s what’s most important" -- Alex Wind, who survived the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.

On the street, at government offices, and via social media: young people are calling for gun control at a national scale. The movement is everywhere, and here are some highlights.
